div.head: General Considerations and Overview
div.p: This chapter describes the TEI encoding mechanisms available for genres of computer-mediated communication (CMC) and thus social media. It is intended to provide the basic framework needed to encode CMC corpora.

While the term “computer-mediated communication” might be used to describe all sorts of communications between humans in the modern age (for example, internet video meetings or cellular telephony), herein we use the term to apply to the more traditional forms of computer-mediated asynchronous communication like text messages, instant messaging, email, chat rooms, online forums, social network services.

The salient feature of these CMC mediums is that a communicative act is generated, typically at the author’s leisure, in the private space of the author, and then transmitted en bloc to the recipient(s). Even though in some CMC genres (e.g., WhatsApp), the other parties are informed by an automated alert about the fact that another party is currently composing a new post, they cannot track the process of verbalization, i.e. how the written utterance emerges in the entry form on the user interface of its author. It is not until the author performs a ‘posting’ action (for example, by hitting the ‘enter’ key or by activating a ‘send’ button with the mouse) that the result of the composition process — the post — is made available for the other parties. From the perspective of its addressees or readers, a post is a stretch of text that has been composed in advance. Different from spoken utterances but similar to edited text, (1) the reader of a post does not have access to the verbalization process and (2) the mental processing of a post is not possible until the process of verbalization (the composition) has been finished and the posting action has been performed by the author. Posts occur in a broad range of written CMC genres, including (but not limited to): as user ‘messages’ in chats and WhatsApp dialogues, as SMS messages, as tweets in Twitter timelines, as individual comments following a status update on Facebook pages, as posts in forum threads, as contributions on Wikipedia talk pages, and in the comments section of a weblog.

div.head: The TEI CMC Module
div.p:
The module described in this chapter makes available the following components:
Elements, Attributes, and Models for Computer-mediated communication (CMC). This module collects all cmc-specific extensions. Hence these will only be added to a TEI schema when this module is selected in a customisation. TEI-CMC Computer-Mediated Communication
